facts.text: The appellant was a monthly tenant of four houses comprised by a single tenancy at a rent of Rs. 250 granted in 1953.

The landlord filed a petition in the Rent Control Court of Kottayam for eviction of the tenant on the ground that he required the premises for his personal use and occupation, and that the tenant was guilty of sub-letting.
The Controller held against the landlord on both points (personal use and sub-letting).
On appeal, the Subordinate Judge held no sub-letting but landlord required premises for personal use; two buildings subject to separate agreements, allowed eviction from two out of four properties.
Both parties filed revision to District Judge, Kottayam under s.20 of Kerala Act 2 of 1965.
Kerala Buildings Lease and Rent Control Act, 1959 repealed by Kerala Buildings Lease and Rent Control Act, 1965 (Act 2 of 1965), which came into force on 1st April, 1965.
District Judge held landlord had not proved bona fide requirement for personal use but there was sub-letting, ordered eviction from all four buildings.
Tenant filed revision to Kerala High Court under s.115 CPC, which dismissed the petition finding no grounds for interference.
Buildings let out as a lodging house; one room occupied by a lawyer for years with name board outside; lawyer paid rent on daily basis, installed telephone in room.
Evidence showed lawyer in exclusive possession of the room.

legal_issues.text: Whether sub-letting by tenant before commencement of 1965 Act is a ground for eviction in proceedings started after repeal of 1959 Act.
Whether District Judge under s.20 of 1965 Act could reverse Subordinate Judge's finding of no sub-letting.
Whether facts established sub-letting within the Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Proceeding for eviction on sub-letting lies only under 1965 Act provisions; sub-s.4 does not make pre-commencement sub-letting a ground.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.11(4) Kerala Buildings Lease and Rent Control Act, 1965

petitioner_arguments.text: S.34(1) proviso saves proceedings under corresponding provisions; s.11(4) of 1959 Act has no corresponding provision in 1965 Act.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.34(1) Kerala Act 1965; s.11(4) Kerala Act 1959

petitioner_arguments.text: S.11(1) of 1965 Act excludes operation of other laws including 1959 Act.
District Court under s.20 could not revise Subordinate Judge's finding against sub-letting confirming Rent Controller.
On facts, no sub-letting; daily rent payment was licence, not sub-letting.

court_reasoning.text: S.34(1) proviso allows proceedings under repealed 1959 Act to continue under corresponding provisions of 1965 Act; s.11(4) of 1959 corresponds to s.11(4) of 1965 as 'correspond' means similar/analogous, not identical.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.34 saves pre-repeal sub-letting grounds via corresponding provisions.

court_reasoning.text: S.11(1) of 1965 does not exclude savings in s.34(1); different intention not apparent to exclude s.4 of Interpretation Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: S.34(1) and s.4 Interpretation Act apply.

court_reasoning.text: S.20 empowers District Court to examine legality, regularity, propriety of orders and pass fit orders; wider than s.115 CPC, not limited to jurisdiction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: District Judge could re-examine sub-letting evidence.

court_reasoning.text: Sufficient evidence of sub-letting: lawyer in exclusive possession with name board, daily rent, telephone; not mere licence. Findings by District Court and High Court not to be interfered with.

holdings.text: Sub-letting prior to 1965 Act commencement is ground for eviction via s.34(1) savings clause and corresponding provisions.
District Judge empowered under s.20 to reverse sub-letting finding.

precedents_cited.citation: Short Notes to Part 1, The Kerala Law Times, 1968 (judgment dated 4th October 1967)
precedents_cited.relevance: Court disagreed with reasoning on savings clause applicability.

statutes_cited.name: Kerala Buildings Lease and Rent Control Act, 1965 (Act 2 of 1965)
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs eviction grounds, savings from repealed Act, revision powers; sub-letting ground applicable via savings.

statutes_cited.name: Kerala Buildings Lease and Rent Control Act, 1959 (Act 16 of 1959)
statutes_cited.relevance: Repealed Act; proceedings saved under 1965 Act's corresponding provisions for sub-letting eviction.

statutes_cited.name: Kerala Interpretation and General Clauses Act, 1125 (Act VII of 1125)
statutes_cited.relevance: Effects of repeal; saves rights, proceedings under repealed enactment.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Revision to High Court; narrower than s.20 of 1965 Act.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal by special leave, upholding the Kerala High Court's dismissal of the tenant's revision, confirming District Judge's order for eviction from all four buildings on ground of sub-letting.
outcome.relief_granted: Eviction of tenant from all four buildings granted to landlord.
outcome.costs: High Court dismissed with costs (no specific Supreme Court costs mentioned).

key_quotes.text: 'To correspond means to be in harmony with or be similar, analogous to. It does not mean to be identical with'
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Defines 'corresponding provision' for savings clause, rejecting strict identity argument.

key_quotes.text: Under s.20(1) the District Court is empowered to call for and examine the records... for the purpose of satisfying itself as to the legality, regularity or propriety... and pass such order... as it thinks fit.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes wide revisional powers beyond jurisdiction.

key_quotes.text: there was sufficient evidence to hold that the lawyer was in exclusive possession of the room and although the rent was paid on a daily basis it was not a case of the grant of a licence.
key_quotes.speaker: court
